page.title: 17THE CHANGING POPULATION
page.content: There are distinct social groupings. Some farms belong to old Devon yeoman families where they have remained for generations e.g.Yellands, Beetor (since 1720) and Shapley. But many have been bought by middle class non-Devonian "escapees" e.g.Hole, Middlecott. Often only a few acres are kept with the house and the rest sold. This has fragmented the old farm units and led to destruction of the old compact community life. Lettaford is an example of a dying community where there are now only holiday cottages looked after by the farmer's widow, whose son drives an ice-cream van. Batworthy, once boasting a baker, blacksmith, and brewery (until 1920),now has 3 derelict cottages in which the young occupants of the mill would like to establish a craft centre community.
